Structure
LinkIdTextCardinalityTypeFlagsDescription & Constraints
EmCare.B18-21.Signs.2m.mQuestionnairehttps://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/Questionnaire/emcare.b18-21.signs.2m.m#0.1.0
Fevernull0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Initial Value: fever
Fever-helpThe client is reported to have or has had fever0..1display
Fever-instructionhelp0..1display
zscorenull0..1decimalExpressions:
  • Initial Value: zscore
AgeInMonthsAge in Month0..1integerExpressions:
  • Initial Value: ageinmonths
AgeInDaysnull0..1integerExpressions:
  • Initial Value: ageindays
EmCare.B20S1.DE01Diarrhoea0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Initial Value: emcare.b20s1.de01
EmCare.A.DE31Biological Mother Vital Status0..1choiceOptions: 3 options
Expressions:
  • Initial Value: emcare.a.de31
EmCare.B21S1.DE01Breastfed0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Initial Value: emcare.b21s1.de01
EmCare.B18S1.DE02Difficulty with Feeding0..1choiceOptions: 3 options
Expressions:
  • Initial Value: emcare.b18s1.de02
YI_sever_but_dheyYI severe classification other than severe dehydration0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Initial Value: yi_sever_but_dhey
YI_severYI severe classification0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Initial Value: yi_sever
EmCare.B7.DE03Convulsion(s) in this Illness0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Initial Value: emcare.b7.de03
EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRatenull0..1group
EmCare.B22.DE01Respiratory Rate (breaths per minute)1..1quantityExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE02').answer.first().empty() and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Respiratory Rate profile').answer.first().empty()
  • Calculated Value: iif(%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Respiratory Rate profile').answer.first().exists(), %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Respiratory Rate profile').answer.first().value,{})
EmCare.B22.DE01-help<b>Count the number of breaths the child takes per minute</b> to determine if fast breathing is present.<br /> It is <b>very important that the child is calm</b> and still. If the child is moving or crying, you will not be able to get an accurate count of breaths. <br /> <b>To count the breaths per minute,</b> use a watch with a second hand or a digital watch. Look for the breathing movement anywhere on the child’s chest or abdomen. <br /> The number of breaths for <b>‘fast breathing’ depends on the child’s age.</b></p> <ul> <li>Under 2 months: More than 60 breaths per minute*</li> <li>2 to 11 months: More than 50 breaths per minute</li> <li>12 to 59 months: More than 40 breaths per minute</li> </ul> <p>*In young infants, a second measurement should be taken to confirm, unless there is already another sign of possible serious bacterial infection0..1display
EmCare.B22.DE02null0..*choiceOptions: 1 option
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE01').answer.first().empty() and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Respiratory Rate profile').answer.first().empty() and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='force-collection').answer.first().value = false
secondnull0..1groupExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInMonths').answer.first().value < 2 and (%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Respiratory Rate profile').answer.first().value > 60 '{Breaths}/min' or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE01').answer.first().value >= 60 '{Breaths}/min') and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Respiratory Rate Second Count Profile').answer.first().empty()
EmCare.B22.DE04Respiratory Rate Second Count (breaths per minute)0..1quantityExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='second').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE05').answer.first().empty()
EmCare.B22.DE04-help<b>Count the number of breaths the child takes per minute</b> to determine if fast breathing is present.<br /> It is <b>very important that the child is calm</b> and still. If the child is moving or crying, you will not be able to get an accurate count of breaths. <br /> <b>To count the breaths per minute,</b> use a watch with a second hand or a digital watch. Look for the breathing movement anywhere on the child’s chest or abdomen. <br /> The number of breaths for <b>‘fast breathing’ depends on the child’s age.</b></p> <ul> <li>Under 2 months: More than 60 breaths per minute*</li> <li>2 to 11 months: More than 50 breaths per minute</li> <li>12 to 59 months: More than 40 breaths per minute</li> </ul> <p>*In young infants, a second measurement should be taken to confirm, unless there is already another sign of possible serious bacterial infection0..1display
EmCare.B22.DE05null0..*choiceOptions: 1 option
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='second').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE04').answer.first().empty()
EmCare.B22.DE07Fast Breathing0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Fast Breathing profile').answer.first().empty() and (%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInMonths').answer.first().value >= 2 or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='second').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE04').answer.first().exists() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='second').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE05').answer.first().exists() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE01').answer.first().value < 60 '{Breaths}/min')
  • Calculated Value: iif(%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Fast Breathing profile').answer.first().empty() and (%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInMonths').answer.first().value >= 2 or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='second').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE04').answer.first().exists() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='second').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE05').answer.first().exists() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE01').answer.first().value < 60 '{Breaths}/min'),iif(%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInMonths').answer.first().value<2 and (%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='second').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE04').answer.first().value >= 60 '{Breaths}/min' or (%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='second').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE05').answer.first().exists() and ( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE01').answer.first().value >= 60 '{Breaths}/min' or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='Respiratory Rate profile').answer.first().value >= 60 '{Breaths}/min' ) ) ) or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE01').answer.first().value >= 50 '{Breaths}/min' and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInMonths').answer.first().value < 12 and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInMonths').answer.first().value >= 2or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.RespiratoryRate').repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B22.DE01').answer.first().value >= 40 '{Breaths}/min' and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInMonths').answer.first().value>=12 and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInMonths').answer.first().value < 60, true, false),{})
EmCare.B22.DE07-helpThe number of breaths for <b>‘fast breathing’ depends on the child’s age.</b> * Under 2 months: More than 60 breaths per minute* * 2 to 11 months: More than 50 breaths per minute * 12 to 59 months: More than 40 breaths per minute *In young infants, a second measurement should be taken to confirm, unless there is already another sign of possible serious bacterial infection0..1display
EmCare.B18S2.DE07Severe Chest Indrawing1..1boolean
EmCare.B18S2.DE07-helpThe young infant must be calm while you assess for severe chest indrawing.  Lift the young infant’s shirt. </p> <p>Look for chest indrawing when the young infant breathes in. Lower chest wall indrawing is the inward movement of the bony structure of the chest wall <br /> when the child breathes in. Look at the lower chest wall (lower ribs). The child has chest indrawing if the lower chest wall goes IN when the child breathes IN.<br /> In normal breathing, the whole chest wall (upper and lower) and the abdomen move <span class="caps">OUT</span> when the child breathes IN. </p> <p>Mild chest indrawing is normal in a young infant because the chest wall is soft. Severe chest indrawing is very deep and easy to see.0..1display
EmCare.B18S2.DE08Movements1..1choiceOptions: 3 options
EmCare.B18S2.DE08-helpLook at the young infant’s movements. Does the young infant move on his/her own? Does the infant move only when stimulated but then stops? Does the infant not move at all?<br /> Young infants often sleep most of the time, and this is not a sign of illness. It is not necessary for the infant to be awake if he/she is moving spontaneously. <br /> If a young infant is not moving spontaneously and does not wake up during the assessment, ask the mother to wake him. An awake young infant will normally move his arms or legs or turn his head several times in a  minute if you watch him closely. If the infant is awake but has no spontaneous movements, gently stimulate the young infant. Stimulation  is a gentle, painless touching of the baby with enough pressure that would evoke movements, sound making and eye opening. The presence of any movement such as a grimace of the face, eye-opening or movement of a limb will qualify “Movement only when stimulated but then stops”.  An infant who cannot be woken up even after stimulation is considered to have the sign “Does not move even with stimulation. “ 0..1display
EmCare.B18S2.DE12Umbilicus Red or Pus Draining1..1boolean
EmCare.B18S2.DE12-help“The umbilical cord usually separates one week after birth and the wound heals within 15 days. Redness of the end of the umbilicus or pus draining from the umbilicus are signs of umbilical infection.” 0..1display
EmCare.B18S2.DE13Skin Pustules1..1boolean
EmCare.B18S2.DE13-helpExamine the skin on the entire body. Skin pustules are red spots or blisters which contain pus.0..1display
EmCare.B19S2.DE01Yellow Skin1..1boolean
EmCare.B19S2.DE01-helpJaundice is a yellow discoloration of skin and mucus membranes. It is important to look for jaundice in natural light. To look for jaundice, press the infant’s skin over the forehead with your fingers to blanch, remove your fingers and look for yellow discolouration. If there is yellow discoloration, the infant has jaundice0..1display
EmCare.B19S2.DE02Yellow Palms or Yellow Soles1..1boolean
EmCare.B19S2.DE02-helpJaundice is a yellow discoloration of skin and mucus membranes. Jaundice in the palms of hands or soles of feet is a sign of Severe Jaundice.  It is important to look for jaundice in natural light. To assess for severe jaundice, press the infant’s skin in the palm of there hand and then in the sole of their feet with your fingers to blanch, remove your finders and look for yellow dicoulouration in the palm or the sole. If there is yellow discoloration of the palm or sole, the infant has severe jaundice.0..1display
EmCare.B19S2.DE04When did the Jaundice first appear?0..1choiceOptions: 3 options
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInDays').answer.first().value >1 and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B19S2.DE01').answer.first().value = true and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B19S2.DE02').answer.first().value = false and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInDays').answer.first().value < 21
EmCare.B19S2.DE04-helpAsk the caregiver when the baby’s skin first turned yellowish. If the caregiver didn’t notice the yellow discolouration or can’t remember when it started, select “don’t know”. <br /> Jaundice that appears in less than 24 hours after birth is always due to an underlying disease. These babies should be referred urgently. <br /> Many normal babies, particularly small babies, may have jaundice during the first week of life. This jaundice usually appears on the third or fourth day of life and is mild and disappears before the age of two to  three weeks. It does not need any treatment.0..1display
EmCare.B11S2.DE01Sunken Eyes1..1booleanExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B20S1.DE01').answer.first().value = true
EmCare.B11S2.DE01-helpThe eyes of a dehydrated infant may look sunken. In a low-weight infant, the eyes may always look sunken, even if the young infant is not dehydrated. Even though the sign “sunken eyes” is less reliable in a low-weight infant, it can still be used to classify the young infant‘s dehydration. </p> <p>Decide if you think the eyes are sunken. Then ask the mother if she thinks her child’s eyes look unusual. Her opinion can help you confirm.0..1display
EmCare.B11S2.DE02Skin pinch of Abdomen1..1choiceOptions: 3 options
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B20S1.DE01').answer.first().value = true
EmCare.B11S2.DE02-helpLocate the area on the infant’s abdomen halfway between the umbilicus and the side of the abdomen. To do the skin pinch, use your thumb and first finger. Do not use your fingertips because this will cause pain. Place <br /> your hand so that when you pinch the skin, the fold of skin will be in a line up and down the child’s body and not across the child’s <br /> body. Firmly pick up all of the layers of skin and the tissue under them. Pinch the skin for <br /> one second and then release it. When you release the skin, look to see if the skin pinch <br /> goes back:</p> <p>• very slowly (longer than 2 seconds)<br /> • slowly<br /> • immediately<br /> If the skin stays up for even a brief time after you release it, decide that the skin pinch goes back slowly0..1display
EmCare.B11S2.DE06Restless and Irritable1..1booleanExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B20S1.DE01').answer.first().value = true and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B18S2.DE08').answer.first().value.code = 'EmCare.B18S2.DE11'
EmCare.B11S2.DE06-helpLook at the young infant’s general condition Is the infant restles and irritable? <br /> An infant has teh sign “restless and irritable” if the infant is restless and irritable all the time or every time he is touched and handled. If an infant is calm when breastfeeding but again <br /> restless and irritable when he stops breastfeeding, he has the sign “restless and irritable”. A healthy infant will be consoled when put on the breast.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE01Weight Status0..1stringExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='zscore').answer.first().exists()
  • Calculated Value: iif(%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='zscore').answer.first().exists(), iif( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='zscore').answer.first().value >= (-2.0), 'Normal Weight for Age', iif( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='zscore').answer.first().value < (-3.0), 'Very Low Weight for Age','Low Weight for Age')), {})
EmCare.B21S2.DE01-helpWeight status is calculated based on the young infant’s weight for age Z-score, which is determined from a standardized chart for weight -for-age for the infant’s sex. <br /> A young infant is low weight for age if the z-score is below -2. <br /> A young infant who is less than 7 days old and weighs less than 2 kg is considered very low weight.<br /> Some young infants who are low weight for age were born with low birth weight. Some did not gain weight well after birth.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE05Breastfed how many times in 24 hours?1..1integerExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value = true and ( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever_but_dhey').answer.empty() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever_but_dhey').answer.first().value=false )
EmCare.B21S2.DE05-helpAsk the caregiver how many times in 24 hours (one day and one night) they usually breastfeed the young infant. The recommendation is that the young infant be breastfed as often and for as long as the <br /> infant wants, day and night. This should be 8 or more times in 24 hours.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE06Sufficient feeds0..1integerExpressions:
  • Calculated Value: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S2.DE05').answer.first().value>= 8
EmCare.B21S2.DE08Young Infant receives food or fluids other than breast milk1..1booleanExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value = true and ( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.empty() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.first().value=false )
EmCare.B21S2.DE08-helpFind out if the young infant is receiving any other foods or drinks such as other milk, juice, tea, thin porridge, dilute cereal, or even water. Ask how often he receives it and the amount. You need to know if the infant is mostly breastfed, or mostly fed on other foods0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE09What milk is being given as a replacement feed?1..*choiceOptions: 2 options
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value= false and ( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.empty() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.first().value=false ) and ( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.empty() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.first().value=false )
EmCare.B21S2.DE09-helpAsk the mother questions to determine what replacement milk or milks are used. It may be a breastmilk replacement, animal milk or some other fluid or some combination. Determine if this type of replacement feed is appropriate or not appropriate in your setting.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE12How many replacement feeds during the day and night (24 hours)?1..1integerExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value= false
EmCare.B21S2.DE12-helpA young infant up to one month of age should be fed 8 times and a young infant between 1 <br /> and 2 months of age should be fed 7 times in 24 hours.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE13Sufficient replacement feeds (in 24 hours)1..1booleanExpressions:
  • Calculated Value: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S2.DE12').answer.first().value>=8
EmCare.B21S2.DE15How much milk is given at each feed (ml)?1..1quantityExpressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value= false
EmCare.B21S2.DE15-helpA young infant up to one month of age should be given approximately 60 ml per feed, 8 times per day, and a young infant between 1 and 2 months of age approximately 90 ml at each feed, 7 times per day. It is helpful to have common bottles or cups available so that a mother can show you the amount that she gives.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE16Sufficient replacement feeds1..1booleanExpressions:
  • Calculated Value: iif(%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='AgeInDays').answer.first().value < 29, %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S2.DE15').answer.first().value>=60 'ml', %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S2.DE15').answer.first().value>=90 'ml' )
EmCare.B21S2.DE18How is the milk prepared?1..1choiceOptions: 2 options
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value= false
EmCare.B21S2.DE18-helpLet mother demonstrate or explain how a feed is prepared and how she gives it to the infant. Determine if the breastmilk substitute is being prepared correctly and hygienically.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE21How is the milk given?1..1choiceOptions: 2 options
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S2.DE08').answer.first().value = true or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value = false
EmCare.B21S2.DE24How are the feeding utensils cleaned?1..1choiceOptions: 2 options
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S2.DE08').answer.first().value = true or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value = false
EmCare.B21S2.DE24-helpAsk the caregiver how they clear the feeding utensils. Determine if this is a safe and hygienic cleaning method.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE27Do you give any breastmilk at all?1..1choiceOptions: 2 options
Expressions:
  • Enable When: %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S1.DE01').answer.first().value = false and ( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.empty() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.first().value=false )
EmCare.B21S2.DE30Ulcers or White Patches in Mouth1..1booleanExpressions:
  • Enable When: ( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.empty() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.first().value=false ) and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S2.DE31').answer.first().empty()
EmCare.B21S2.DE30-helpLook inside the mouth at the tongue and inside of the cheek. Thrush looks like milk curds on the inside of the cheek, or a thick white coating of the tongue. Try to wipe the white off. The white patches of thrush will remain.0..1display
EmCare.B21S2.DE31null0..*choiceOptions: 1 option
Expressions:
  • Enable When: ( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.empty() or %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='YI_sever').answer.first().value=false ) and %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='EmCare.B21S2.DE30').answer.first().empty()
Respiratory Rate profilenull0..1quantityExpressions:
  • Initial Value: respiratory rate profile
force-collectionnull0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Initial Value: force-collection
Respiratory Rate Second Count Profilenull0..1quantityExpressions:
  • Initial Value: respiratory rate second count profile
Fast Breathing profilenull0..1booleanExpressions:
  • Initial Value: fast breathing profile
timestampnull0..1dateTimeExpressions:
  • Calculated Value: now()

Documentation for this format

Option Sets

Answer options for EmCare.A.DE31

  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.A.DE46 ("Dead")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.A.DE34 ("Alive")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.A.DE33 ("Unknown")

Answer options for EmCare.B18S1.DE02

  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B18S1.DE03 ("Not Able to Feed At All")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B18S1.DE04 ("Not Feeding Well")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B18S1.DE05 ("Feeding Well")

Answer options for EmCare.B22.DE02

  • null#EmCare.B22.DE02 ("Unable to perform Respiratory Rate at this time")

Answer options for EmCare.B22.DE05

  • null#EmCare.B22.DE05 ("Respiratory Rate Second Count Not Possible")

Answer options for EmCare.B18S2.DE08

  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B18S2.DE11 ("Moves on his or her own or moves spontaneously or without stimulation")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B18S2.DE10 ("Movement only when stimulated but then stops")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B18S2.DE09 ("No movement at all")

Answer options for EmCare.B19S2.DE04

  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B19S2.DE05 ("Within less than 24 hours of birth")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B19S2.DE06 ("24 hours or more after birth")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B19S2.DE07 ("Unknown when Jaundice first appeared")

Answer options for EmCare.B11S2.DE02

  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B20S2.DE03 ("Skin Pinch goes back very slowly (More than 2 seconds)")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B20S2.DE04 ("Skin Pinch goes back slowly (2 seconds or fewer, but not immediately)")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B20S2.DE05 ("Skin Pinch goes back Normally (immediately)")

Answer options for EmCare.B21S2.DE09

  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B21S2.DE11 ("Inappropriate replacement milk")
  • https://fhir.dk.swisstph-mis.ch/matchbox/fhir/CodeSystem/emcare-custom-codes#EmCare.B21S2.DE10 ("Appropriate replacement milk")

item.text: The client is reported to have or has had fever

Breastfed

valueCoding.display: Not Able to Feed At All

item.text: YI severe classification other than severe dehydration
YI severe classification
Convulsion(s) in this Illness
Respiratory Rate (breaths per minute)

Count the number of breaths the child takes per minute to determine if fast breathing is present.
It is very important that the child is calm and still. If the child is moving or crying, you will not be able to get an accurate count of breaths.
To count the breaths per minute, use a watch with a second hand or a digital watch. Look for the breathing movement anywhere on the child’s chest or abdomen.
The number of breaths for ‘fast breathing’ depends on the child’s age.

  • Under 2 months: More than 60 breaths per minute*
  • 2 to 11 months: More than 50 breaths per minute
  • 12 to 59 months: More than 40 breaths per minute

*In young infants, a second measurement should be taken to confirm, unless there is already another sign of possible serious bacterial infection

valueCoding.display: Unable to perform Respiratory Rate at this time

item.text: Respiratory Rate Second Count (breaths per minute)

Count the number of breaths the child takes per minute to determine if fast breathing is present.
It is very important that the child is calm and still. If the child is moving or crying, you will not be able to get an accurate count of breaths.
To count the breaths per minute, use a watch with a second hand or a digital watch. Look for the breathing movement anywhere on the child’s chest or abdomen.
The number of breaths for ‘fast breathing’ depends on the child’s age.

  • Under 2 months: More than 60 breaths per minute*
  • 2 to 11 months: More than 50 breaths per minute
  • 12 to 59 months: More than 40 breaths per minute

*In young infants, a second measurement should be taken to confirm, unless there is already another sign of possible serious bacterial infection

item.text: Fast Breathing

The number of breaths for ‘fast breathing’ depends on the child’s age. * Under 2 months: More than 60 breaths per minute* * 2 to 11 months: More than 50 breaths per minute * 12 to 59 months: More than 40 breaths per minute *In young infants, a second measurement should be taken to confirm, unless there is already another sign of possible serious bacterial infection
Severe Chest Indrawing

The young infant must be calm while you assess for severe chest indrawing.  Lift the young infant’s shirt.

Look for chest indrawing when the young infant breathes in. Lower chest wall indrawing is the inward movement of the bony structure of the chest wall
when the child breathes in. Look at the lower chest wall (lower ribs). The child has chest indrawing if the lower chest wall goes IN when the child breathes IN.
In normal breathing, the whole chest wall (upper and lower) and the abdomen move OUT when the child breathes IN.

Mild chest indrawing is normal in a young infant because the chest wall is soft. Severe chest indrawing is very deep and easy to see.
Movements

valueCoding.display: Moves on his or her own or moves spontaneously or without stimulation
Movement only when stimulated but then stops

item.text: Umbilicus Red or Pus Draining

“The umbilical cord usually separates one week after birth and the wound heals within 15 days.  Redness of the end of the umbilicus or pus draining from the umbilicus are signs of umbilical  infection.”
Skin Pustules
Examine the skin on the entire body. Skin pustules are red spots or blisters which contain pus.
Yellow Skin

Jaundice is a yellow discoloration of skin and mucus membranes. It is important to look for jaundice in natural light. To look for jaundice, press the  infant’s skin over the forehead with your fingers to blanch, remove your fingers and look for yellow discolouration. If there is yellow discoloration, the infant has jaundice
Yellow Palms or Yellow Soles

Jaundice is a yellow discoloration of skin and mucus membranes. Jaundice in the palms of hands or soles of feet is a sign of Severe Jaundice.  It is important to look for jaundice in natural light. To assess for severe jaundice, press the infant’s skin in the palm of there hand and then in the sole of their feet with your fingers to blanch, remove your finders and look for yellow dicoulouration in the palm or the sole. If there is yellow discoloration of the palm or sole, the infant has severe jaundice.
When did the Jaundice first appear?

valueCoding.display: Within less than 24 hours of birth

item.text:
Ask the caregiver when the baby’s skin first turned yellowish. If the caregiver didn’t notice the yellow discolouration or can’t remember when it started, select “don’t know”.
Jaundice that appears in less than 24 hours after birth is always due to an underlying disease. These babies should be referred urgently.
Many normal babies, particularly small babies, may have jaundice during the first week of life. This jaundice usually appears on the third or fourth day of life and is mild and disappears before the age of two to  three weeks. It does not need any treatment.
Sunken Eyes

The eyes of a dehydrated infant may look sunken. In a low-weight infant, the eyes may always look sunken, even if the young infant is not dehydrated. Even though the sign “sunken eyes” is less reliable in a low-weight infant, it can still be used to classify the young infant‘s dehydration.

Decide if you think the eyes are sunken. Then ask the mother if she thinks her child’s eyes look unusual. Her opinion can help you confirm.
Skin pinch of Abdomen

valueCoding.display: Skin Pinch goes back very slowly (More than 2 seconds)
Skin Pinch goes back slowly (2 seconds or fewer, but not immediately)

item.text:
Locate the area on the infant’s abdomen halfway between the umbilicus and the side of the abdomen. To do the skin pinch, use your thumb and first finger. Do not use your fingertips because this will cause pain. Place
your hand so that when you pinch the skin, the fold of skin will be in a line up and down the child’s body and not across the child’s
body. Firmly pick up all of the layers of skin and the tissue under them. Pinch the skin for
one second and then release it. When you release the skin, look to see if the skin pinch
goes back:

• very slowly (longer than 2 seconds)
• slowly
• immediately
If the skin stays up for even a brief time after you release it, decide that the skin pinch goes back slowly
Restless and Irritable

Look at the young infant’s general condition Is the infant restles and irritable?
An infant has teh sign “restless and irritable” if the infant is restless and irritable all the time or every time he is touched and handled. If an infant is calm when breastfeeding but again
restless and irritable when he stops breastfeeding, he has the sign “restless and irritable”. A healthy infant will be consoled when put on the breast.

valueExpression.expression: iif(%resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='zscore').answer.first().exists(), iif( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='zscore').answer.first().value >= (-2.0), 'Normal Weight for Age', iif( %resource.repeat(item).where(linkId='zscore').answer.first().value < (-3.0), 'Very Low Weight for Age','Low Weight for Age')), {})

item.text: Weight Status

Weight status is calculated based on the young infant’s weight for age Z-score, which is determined from a standardized chart for weight -for-age for the infant’s sex.
A young infant is low weight for age if the z-score is below -2.
A young infant who is less than 7 days old and weighs less than 2 kg is considered very low weight.
Some young infants who are low weight for age were born with low birth weight. Some did not gain weight well after birth.
Breastfed how many times in 24 hours?

Ask the caregiver how many times in 24 hours (one day and one night) they usually breastfeed the young infant. The recommendation is that the young infant be breastfed as often and for as long as the
infant wants, day and night. This should be 8 or more times in 24 hours.
Sufficient feeds
Young Infant receives food or fluids other than breast milk

Find out if the young infant is receiving any other foods or drinks such as other milk, juice, tea, thin porridge, dilute cereal, or even water. Ask how often he receives it and the amount. You need to know if the infant is mostly breastfed, or mostly fed on other foods
What milk is being given as a replacement feed?

Ask the mother questions to determine what replacement milk or milks are used. It may be a breastmilk replacement, animal milk or some other fluid or some combination. Determine if this type of replacement feed is appropriate or not appropriate in your setting.
How many replacement feeds during the day and night (24 hours)?

A young infant up to one month of age should be fed 8 times and a young infant between 1
and 2 months of age should be fed 7 times in 24 hours.
Sufficient replacement feeds (in 24 hours)
How much milk is given at each feed (ml)?

A young infant up to one month of age should be given approximately 60 ml per feed, 8 times per day, and a young infant between 1 and 2 months of age approximately 90 ml at each feed, 7 times per day. It is helpful to have common bottles or cups available so that a mother can show you the amount that she gives.
Sufficient replacement feeds
How is the milk prepared?
Let mother demonstrate or explain how a feed is prepared and how she gives it to the infant. Determine if the breastmilk substitute is being prepared correctly and hygienically.
How is the milk given?
How are the feeding utensils cleaned?
Ask the caregiver how they clear the feeding utensils. Determine if this is a safe and hygienic cleaning method.
Do you give any breastmilk at all?
Ulcers or White Patches in Mouth

Look inside the mouth at the tongue and inside of the cheek. Thrush looks like milk curds on the inside of the cheek, or a thick white coating of the tongue. Try to wipe the white off. The white patches of thrush will remain.

valueCoding.display: Unable to check if Ulcers or White Patches in Mouth
